title: 110_hr554
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Paleontological Resources Preservation Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The "Paleontological Resources Preservation Act" defines key terms such as casual collecting and Secretary, with the Secretary being either the Secretary of the Interior or the Secretary of Agriculture for different types of lands. The "Paleontological Resources Preservation Act" defines terms related to lands controlled by the Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of the Interior, including Federal lands, National Forest System lands, Indian lands, and States. The "Paleontological Resources Preservation Act" defines paleontological resources as fossilized remains, traces, or imprints of organisms that provide information about the history of life on earth, excluding materials associated with archaeological resources or cultural items. The Secretary is responsible for managing and protecting paleontological resources on Federal lands using scientific principles. Plans for inventory, monitoring, and use of resources must be developed, emphasizing coordination with non-Federal partners and the public. The Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture should coordinate efforts. Additionally, a public awareness and education program will be established, and there will be a collection of paleontological resources. Permits are required to collect paleontological resources on Federal lands, except for casual collecting on certain lands without a permit. Valid permits issued before the enactment of this Act are not affected. The Secretary may issue a permit for collection if certain criteria are met. The Secretary may issue a permit for the collection of a paleontological resource if the applicant is qualified, the activity furthers paleontological knowledge or public education, is consistent with management plans, and methods of collecting do not threaten natural or cultural resources. Permits will include necessary terms and conditions to carry out the purposes of the Act. Permits issued under this Act require that collected paleontological resources remain the property of the United States, be preserved in an approved repository for public access, and not disclose specific locality data without permission from the Secretary. The Secretary has the authority to modify, suspend, or revoke permits for various reasons. The Secretary may restrict access or close areas under their jurisdiction to protect paleontological resources and ensure public safety. Permits can be revoked if a person working under the permit is convicted under section 7 or assessed a civil penalty under section 8. SEC. 6. CURATION OF RESOURCES. Paleontological resources collected under a permit must be deposited in an approved repository. The Secretary can make agreements with non-Federal repositories for curation. SEC. 7. PROHIBITED ACTS; CRIMINAL PENALTIES. A person is prohibited from excavating, damaging, or altering paleontological resources on Federal lands without following the regulations. It is also illegal to exchange, transport, export, receive, or sell these resources if they were obtained unlawfully from Federal lands. A person may not excavate, damage, or alter paleontological resources on Federal lands without following regulations. It is also illegal to exchange, transport, export, receive, or sell these resources if obtained unlawfully. Violators may face fines, imprisonment, or both, depending on the value of the resources involved. If the sum of the commercial and paleontological value of the resources involved and the cost of restoration does not exceed $500, the person will be fined or imprisoned. There is a general exception for any person who lawfully possessed the paleontological resource before the enactment of this Act. SEC. 8. CIVIL PENALTIES. The Secretary may assess penalties for violations of regulations or permits under the Act, with each violation considered a separate offense. The penalty amount is determined based on factors such as the value of the paleontological resource and the cost of response and restoration. The Secretary may assess penalties for violations under the Act based on factors like the cost of response, restoration, and repair of the resource and paleontological site. For multiple offenses by the same person, the penalty amount may be doubled, with a limitation on the maximum penalty amount for any one violation. Additionally, there is a provision for judicial review and collection of unpaid assessments. The judicial review process allows individuals to challenge penalties assessed under the Act within a 30-day period in the United States District Court. The court will review the action based on substantial evidence from the record before the Secretary. The Secretary will sustain the action if supported by substantial evidence on the record. Failure to pay the penalty within 30 days may result in the Attorney General instituting a civil action in a district court. The district court has jurisdiction to collect penalties for non-payment, with interest and additional fees for collection proceedings. The validity and amount of the penalty are not subject to review in court. Penalties collected under this section may be used to protect, restore, or repair paleontological resources and sites, acquire sites with equivalent resources, and provide educational materials to the public. Hearings during proceedings shall be conducted in accordance with section 554 of title 5, United States Code. The Federal lands' organic legislation limits shall apply. Educational materials on paleontological resources to be provided to the public. Rewards payment as per section 9. Rewards payment as per section 9. The Secretary may pay rewards from penalties collected under section 7 or 8, based on regulations or a set amount, to individuals providing information leading to civil or criminal violations. No government officials are eligible for payment. All paleontological resources are subject to forfeiture. All paleontological resources involved in violations under this Act may be subject to civil or criminal forfeiture, including vehicles and equipment used in the violation. The Secretary has the authority to transfer seized resources as needed. The Secretary has the authority to transfer seized paleontological resources to educational institutions for scientific or educational purposes. SEC. 10. CONFIDENTIALITY.

Information about paleontological resources requiring a permit is exempt from disclosure unless it furthers the Act's purposes, poses no risk to the resource, and complies with other laws.

SEC. 11. REGULATIONS.

The Secretary will issue regulations to implement the Act, allowing for public input.

SEC. 12. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. Nothing in this Act shall invalidate, modify, or impose additional restrictions on activities permitted under various mining and land management laws. The Act does not affect activities permitted under existing laws related to Federal lands, casual collecting of certain resources, recovery from non-Federal lands, additional protection for paleontological resources, or create new rights or benefits. The Act does not create any new rights, privileges, benefits, or entitlements for individuals not employed by the United States. Non-government individuals cannot file civil actions in federal courts to enforce provisions of the Act. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out the Act.
